docs.lead_paragraph: Health insurance premiums for federal workers and retirees will rise next year by an average of 10.6 percent, which is much less than the increases planned by many private employers, the Bush administration said today. Administration officials said the new rates suggested that the federal employee program was a model for the private sector and for Medicare, the insurance program for people who are elderly or disabled.

headline.main: Federal Workers' Health Premiums to Rise Less Than Others'

docs.abstract: Health insurance premiums for federal workers and retirees will rise in 2004 by average of 10.6 percent, much less than increases planned by many private employers; Bush administration officials say new rates suggest that federal employee program, which offers wide variety of insurance options through scores of competing private health plans, is model for private sector and for Medicare (M)
docs.snippet: Health insurance premiums for federal workers and retirees will rise next year by an average of 10.6 percent, which is much less than the increases planned by many private employers, the Bush administration said today.    Administration officials...

docs.lead_paragraph: With the ranks of the uninsured rising rapidly across the country, California -- where the problem is especially acute -- is on the verge of requiring thousands of employers to provide health benefits for their workers. Gov. Gray Davis is expected to pause in his struggle to survive a recall vote and sign a new health care mandate into law early next month, state officials said. After earlier action in the State Assembly, the State Senate passed the measure early on Saturday in a party line vote, with Democrats in favor and Republicans opposed.

headline.main: Many California Employers Face Health Care Mandate

docs.abstract: Gov Gray Davis is expected to sign legislation requiring thousands of employers in California to provide health benefits to their employees or pay into new state fund to cover the uninsured; employers affected will be those with 200 or more employees starting in 2006, those with 50 to 200 employees starting 2007 and those with 25 to 50 workers later, but only if state arranges tax credits to help them; backers, who include doctors, and labor representatives, say measure will extend coverage to more than one million of state's seven million uninsured people at cost of $1.5 billion a year, but business groups that oppose it say law will cost businesses $7.2 billion a year, undermine jobs and economy and drive some businesses out of state; graphs give profile of the uninsured in California (M)
docs.snippet: With the ranks of the uninsured rising rapidly across the country, California -- where the problem is especially acute -- is on the verge of requiring thousands of employers to provide health benefits for their workers.    Gov. Gray Davis is expected...

docs.lead_paragraph: If there was one thing Americans had a right to expect from Congress, it was a federal plan to help the elderly pay for prescription drugs. It is a promise that has been made again and again -- in particularly high decibels during the last presidential election. The House and Senate have passed bills, and although both are flawed, this page has urged Congress to finish work on them as a first step toward fulfilling this longstanding commitment. Unfortunately, things have changed. The government cannot afford the program now. That is the fault of President Bush and the Republican majorities in the House and Senate. They broke the bank with their enormous tax cuts. The country is facing the largest budget deficit in history, and there is no realistic plan for getting it under control. The limited version of a prescription drug benefit now being considered in Congress would cost about $400 billion over 10 years.
docs.abstract: Editorial says federal government will have to abandon $400 billion plan to help the elderly pay for prescription drugs because only way to pay for it is through borrowing; says fault lies with Pres Bush and Republican majorities in House and Senate, who have driven up federal budget deficit with their enormous tax cuts; charges that some of these cuts are designed to create deficit that will give Republicans excuse to beat back popular entitlement programs
docs.snippet: If there was one thing Americans had a right to expect from Congress, it was a federal plan to help the elderly pay for prescription drugs. It is a promise that has been made again and again -- in particularly high decibels during the last...

docs.lead_paragraph: As Congress works on legislation to cover prescription drugs under Medicare, lawmakers have been deluged with complaints from retirees who fear losing drug benefits they already have from former employers. Some lawmakers say this issue is emerging as the most immediate threat to the legislation.

headline.main: RETIREES ALARMED AT THREAT OF CUTS IN DRUG BENEFITS

docs.abstract: Some lawmakers say mounting fear of retirees of losing drug benefits they already have from former employers poses most immediate threat to legislation to cover prescription drugs under Medicare; Medicare generally does not cover outpatient prescription drugs, but some employers voluntarily provide such coverage; members of Congress now realize that any Medicare drug benefit they may approve will have profound effect on health coverage provided to retirees by former employers; as result, Congress is frantically seeking ways to address concern, by offering tax credits, subsidies or other incentives for employers to continue providing drug benefits to retirees; about 12 million of 40 million Medicare recipeints have retiree health benefits, usually including some drug benefits; Congressional Budget Office estimates that one-third of people with such drug coverage could lose it under bills pased in June by House and Senate; photo (M)
docs.snippet: As Congress works on legislation to cover prescription drugs under Medicare, lawmakers have been deluged with complaints from retirees who fear losing drug benefits they already have from former employers.    Some lawmakers say this issue is emerging...

docs.lead_paragraph: The medical oddballs today who feel shunned by mainstream practitioners can take comfort, for better or worse, in a new mini-series on medical history that makes heroes of fanatical scientists of yesteryear. To say the least, they lacked tact. Imagine the reaction to Dr. Ignaz Semmelweis, a surly Hungarian, who called his colleagues murderers because they refused to wash their hands between autopsies and delivering babies. He was onto something (hygiene) but lacked people skills. Dr. Semmelweis died in a mental hospital, but hand-washing eventually caught on.

headline.main: Medical History's Oddballs Go Prime Time

docs.abstract: Mavericks, Miracles and Medicine, new mini-series for History Channel, tells story of early medical pioneers; writer and director Jeffrey Tuchman comments; Dr Ignaz Semmelweis, proponent of hand-washing, Andreas Vesalius, infamous grave-robbing father of anatomy, and microscope inventor Antoni van Leeuwenhoek are some of founders of modern medicine who are discussed in show; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: The medical oddballs today who feel shunned by mainstream practitioners can take comfort, for better or worse, in a new mini-series on medical history that makes heroes of fanatical scientists of yesteryear. To say the least, they lacked tact.    ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Nassau County has ''turned the critical corner'' in its fiscal crisis and is now rebounding, County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi said today as he proposed a new budget with no new taxes. No longer is Nassau ''the poster child for failed government,'' Mr. Suozzi said in his speech here. He was referring to Nassau's deficit-ridden past, which led to a state bailout and the imposition of a fiscal review board.

headline.main: Nassau Executive Offers Budget With No New Taxes

docs.abstract: Nassau County Exec Thomas R Suozzi offers $2.3 billion budget for 2004, ith no new taxes and no further cuts to county government; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Nassau County has ''turned the critical corner'' in its fiscal crisis and is now rebounding, County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi said today as he proposed a new budget with no new taxes.    No longer is Nassau ''the poster child for failed...

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite a government recommendation that people with asthma receive annual flu vaccinations, only about a third do so, a new study reports. Among people ages 18 to 49 the figure is even lower -- about one in five, researchers write in the journal Chest. For those 50 to 64, the rate is about 45 percent. Higher vaccination rates were associated not just with being older, but also with being better educated.
docs.abstract: Researchers writing in journal Chest have determined that people with asthma are at greater risk for influenza complications and should get flu vaccine; data was gathered from federal health surveys between 1991 and 2001 (S)
docs.snippet: Despite a government recommendation that people with asthma receive annual flu vaccinations, only about a third do so, a new study reports.    Among people ages 18 to 49 the figure is even lower -- about one in five, researchers write in the journal...

docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
docs.abstract: In this lesson, students examine the differences between various state constitutions in the United States. Then, using their own "constitutional language," they write a preamble and three articles for a constitution intended for their school or local community.

byline.original: By ANNISSA HAMBOUZ and YASMIN CHIN EISENHAUER

docs.lead_paragraph: A growing number of New Yorkers -- including those with jobs -- do not have health insurance, according to a new study. The study found that from 1999 to 2001, nearly 1 in 10 upstate residents were uninsured and nearly 2 in 10 residents in New York City and its suburbs from Westchester to Long Island were uninsured. The study was released Friday by Excellus Blue Cross-Blue Shield of western New York.

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Health Coverage Low, Study Says

docs.abstract: Number of New Yorkers without health insurance is rising, and includes those with jobs (S)
